questions.text: What is the investigation of choice in varicose vein? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duplex scan

 

The investigation of choice for varicose veins is a duplex scan. A duplex scan, also known as a venous Doppler or venous duplex, is a non-invasive ultrasound method that allows visualization of the veins and the blood flow within them. It is particularly useful for identifying the location and extent of venous incompetence, such as at the sapheno-femoral junction and in perforator veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plethysmography: It is not the first-line investigation for varicose veins.

 

Option C. MRI: It may be used in more complex cases where detailed imaging is required.

 

Option D. CT: CT scans are not the primary choice for evaluating varicose veins due to the limited ability to assess venous blood flow and venous incompetence compared to a duplex scan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The duplex scan is the investigation of choice for varicose veins, providing detailed information on venous blood flow and identifying sites of venous incompetence.

questions.text: Calculate the percentage of burns in a 6-year-old child whose head and neck was burnt in an accident at school? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 18%

 

As per Lund and Browder chart the percentage of burns in this child would be 18%.

 

For the 1-9 years age group, the Lund-Browder chart is divided into the following regions:

 

  1. Head and Neck: 18%
  2. Anterior Trunk: 18%
  3. Posterior Trunk: 18%
  4. Each Arm: 9%
  5. Each Leg: 14%
  6. Perineum: 1%

 

The Lund-Browder chart is a tool used to estimate the total body surface area (TBSA) of burns in paediatric patients. It is divided into regions that correspond to different percentages of TBSA, and each region is assigned a different percentage based on the age of the patient. The chart takes into account the fact that the proportion of body surface area represented by different body parts changes as a child grows.

 

The chart is divided into three age groups: 0-1 year, 1-9 years, and 9-17 years. Each age group has its own chart with different regions and percentages. The regions are further divided into sub-regions to allow for more accurate estimation of the TBSA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 9%: For a 6-year-old child, 9% represents the TBSA of each arm. This does not correspond to the head and neck region.

 

Option C. 27%: There is no single region in the Lund-Browder chart for the 1-9 years age group that accounts for 27% of the TBSA. The head and neck alone are 18%.

 

Option D. 36%: This percentage does not correspond to any single region or combination of the head and neck in the Lund-Browder chart for a child of this age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding the Lund and Browder chart is essential for accurately assessing burn injuries in pediatric patients.
  • For children aged 1-9 years, the head and neck region accounts for 18% of the TBSA.
  • This knowledge is crucial for determining the appropriate treatment and management of burn injuries in children.

questions.text: In indirect inguinal hernia surgery, which nerve is most commonly injured? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Genitofemoral

 

In the context of Lichtenstein's hernia repair, which is an open mesh repair for inguinal hernias, the ilioinguinal nerve is the most likely to be injured, it was not listed as an option in this question. Therefore, the genitofemoral nerve is the best answer among the given choices.

 

This is because the genitofemoral nerve runs within the spermatic cord, which can be manipulated during the surgery. During the separation of the hernia sac from the spermatic cord, there is a risk of injuring the genitofemoral nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral: The femoral nerve is too large and lies deeper within the body, making it less likely to be injured during an inguinal hernia repair.

 

Option C. Obturator: The obturator nerve is not typically associated with inguinal hernia anatomy and is not at risk during these surgeries.

 

Option D. Pudendal: The pudendal nerve is related to the pelvic region and is not typically involved in the anatomy of an inguinal hernia repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In open inguinal hernia repairs, particularly Lichtenstein's hernia repair, the ilioinguinal nerve >> genitofemoral nerve is at risk of injury due to its location within the spermatic cord and very rarely iliohypogastric nerve can be injured.

 

In laparoscopic hernia repair, there is a risk of injuring nerves such as the lateral cutaneous nerve, anterior cutaneous nerve, and femoral nerve.

questions.text: Spread of prostate cancer to lumbar vertebra occurs via? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Venous

 

Explanation:

 

Prostate cancer spreads to lumbar vertebrae through:

 

  • Bateson's venous plexus (vertebral venous plexus)
  • This is a valveless system allowing bidirectional flow
  • Connects prostatic venous plexus to vertebral veins
  • Most common cancer in men with bone metastasis
  • Typically produces osteoblastic lesions in bones

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct: Incorrect as prostate is anatomically distant from lumbar vertebrae making direct spread impossible

 

Option B. Arterial: Incorrect as prostatic venous plexus connection to vertebrae via Bateson's plexus is the established pathway

 

Option D. Lymphatic: Incorrect as lymphatic spread of prostate cancer is typically to pelvic and para-aortic nodes, not directly to vertebrae

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prostate cancer spreads to lumbar vertebrae through Bateson's venous plexus, making it the most common cancer in men with bone metastasis.



Spread of CA Prostate

choices.text: Wide excision of the lactiferous duct.

questions.text: Identify the surgical procedure that involves the removal of a small segment of the lactiferous duct, typically from the breast in which a probe is inserted into the duct from which the discharge is emerging. A tennis racquet incision is made, and the flap is dissected to reach the duct. The duct is then excised. This procedure is known as? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Microdochectomy

 

  • Microdochectomy is a surgical procedure that involves removing a discharging lactiferous duct.
  • The procedure is typically performed on patients with duct papilloma or duct ectasia involving a single duct.
  • During the procedure, a probe or stiff nylon suture is inserted into the duct from which the discharge is emerging.
  • An incision can be made in the shape of a tennis racquet to encompass the entire duct, or a periareolar incision may be used to access the duct by dissecting the nipple flap.
  • The affected duct is then excised or removed, and the tissue is sent for further evaluation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Macrodochectomy: Macrodochectomy refers to the removal of a larger or major segment of the lactiferous duct. This procedure can be undertaken when there are multiple pathologies within the duct, making it necessary to excise a more substantial portion of the duct system.

 

Option C. Cone excision: In breast surgery, it might mean the removal of a cone-shaped segment of tissue which includes a problematic area, such as a localized tumor. The goal is often to ensure that the margins of the removed tissue are clear of any pathological changes.

 

Option D. Wide excision of the lactiferous duct: This procedure involves removing a more extensive portion of the lactiferous duct, typically more than in a microdochectomy. The objective here might be to ensure that the entirety of a problematic duct or surrounding tissue is removed, especially if there is a concern about a larger segment of the duct being involved with a disease process.

 

Educational Objective:


Microdochectomy is the surgical removal of a discharging lactiferous duct, commonly performed for cases of single-duct pathologies like duct papilloma or duct ectasia.

questions.text: An adult male is presented with duodenal ulcer is offered various surgical options for its treatment. Which of the surgical options listed below causes least side effects with good healing of ulcers?  (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Highly selective vagotomy
 

Duodenal ulcers can be caused by Helicobacter pylori infection, increased acid secretion, or the use of NSAIDs. When medical management is ineffective or complications arise, surgical treatment may be necessary. Among the surgical options, a highly selective vagotomy (HSV) is preferred due to its ability to effectively reduce acid secretion while causing the least side effects and offering good ulcer healing.

  • This procedure, also known as parietal cell vagotomy or proximal gastric vagotomy, targets only the vagal nerve fibers that stimulate acid-producing parietal cells in the stomach. It spares the vagal innervation to the antrum, pylorus, and the remaining abdominal viscera.
  • By preserving the innervation to the antrum and pylorus, HSV maintains more normal gastric function, reducing the risk of side effects such as delayed gastric emptying and diarrhea.
  • This makes it the surgical option with the least side effects and a good rate of ulcer healing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Truncal Vagotomy:

 

  • Involves dividing the main trunk of the vagus nerve as it enters the abdomen, significantly reducing parasympathetic stimulation to the stomach and decreasing gastric acid secretion.
  • Although effective in reducing acid secretion, it often causes significant side effects, including delayed gastric emptying and diarrhea, due to the loss of vagal control over the entire stomach and other abdominal organs.

 

Option B. Selective Vagotomy:

 

  • Selectively cuts the vagus nerve fibers supplying the stomach while preserving the nerve supply to the pylorus, liver, and biliary system.
  • Reduces acid secretion less than truncal vagotomy but preserves more normal stomach function. However, it is still associated with more side effects compared to highly selective vagotomy.

 

Option D. Gastrojejunostomy:

 

  • Creates a new connection between the stomach and the jejunum, bypassing the duodenum where the ulcer is located.
  • Does not reduce acid secretion and does not address the underlying cause of the ulcer. It is typically performed for ulcer complications or in combination with other procedures. It may be associated with dumping syndrome and other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The highly selective vagotomy (HSV) is the preferred surgical option for chronic duodenal ulcers due to its effective reduction of acid secretion, minimal side effects, and good ulcer healing rate.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents to the clinic with complaints of oral ulcers and a burning sensation in the mouth. A picture of the patient's oral cavity is provided, which reveals several white patches on the tongue and inner cheek. Based on this presentation, what is the likely diagnosis for this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leukoplakia

 

  • Leukoplakia is characterized by the presence of white patches on the oral mucosa, which cannot be scraped off.
  • The patches may vary in appearance, from smooth to rough or nodular.
  • Common risk factors include tobacco use (both smoking and smokeless forms) and chronic alcohol consumption.
  • While it's a benign lesion, there is a risk of malignant transformation, which is why regular monitoring and biopsy of suspicious areas are vital.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Erythroplakia: Erythroplakia is less common than leukoplakia but has a higher potential for being either cancerous at the time of diagnosis or becoming malignant later. It appears as red patches or plaques and is often more concerning due to its higher risk of malignancy.

 

Option C. Submucosal fibrosis: Oral submucous fibrosis is a chronic, progressive scarring disease, mostly linked to areca nut (betel nut) chewing. It's particularly prevalent in the Indian subcontinent. It's characterized by stiffness of the oral mucosa leading to trismus (difficulty in opening the mouth), burning sensation on eating spicy food, and oral ulcers. Over time, the condition can progress, making it hard for the patient to open their mouth. This condition also has a risk of malignant transformation, and like leukoplakia, requires regular monitoring.

 

Option D. Malakoplakia: Malakoplakia is a rare inflammatory condition that can affect various organs, including the bladder, kidneys, and even the gastrointestinal tract. In the context of the oral cavity, it's extremely rare. It presents as soft yellow plaques. Histologically, it's characterized by the presence of unique cells called "Michaelis-Gutmann bodies".

 

  • Given the presentation described - white patches on the tongue and inner cheek of a chronic alcohol abuser - the diagnosis of leukoplakia (option A) is the most probable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leukoplakia is an oral mucosal lesion characterized by white patches that cannot be scraped off and is commonly associated with tobacco and alcohol use.
  • It has the potential for malignant transformation, necessitating regular monitoring and biopsy of suspicious areas.

questions.text: What is the Z-plasty surgical technique? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Technique for Scar Lengthening

 

Z-plasty is a plastic surgery technique used for scar lengthening and contracture release. It involves creating two triangular transposition flaps on either side of a scar or contracture, typically at 45-60 degree angles, forming a Z-shape. When these flaps are transposed (exchanged in position), the central limb of the Z is lengthened, effectively releasing contractures and reorienting scars along relaxed skin tension lines. 

 

 

The image demonstrates the classic steps: initial Z-incision design, flap elevation, and final transposition. This technique gains length by recruiting lateral tissue and can achieve 25-75% lengthening depending on the angles used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Technique of pedicled flap creation: Incorrect. While Z-plasty uses local flaps, it specifically creates transposition flaps, not pedicled flaps. Pedicled flaps maintain a vascular pedicle and are transferred to distant sites, whereas Z-plasty flaps are locally transposed.

 

Option C. Zigzag suture technique: Incorrect. Although the final scar appears zigzag-shaped, Z-plasty is not a suturing technique but a surgical procedure involving tissue rearrangement through flap transposition.

 

Option D. Technique of giving injection: Incorrect. The Z-track injection technique for intramuscular medications (pulling tissue laterally before injection) is completely different from Z-plasty surgical technique and should not be confused despite similar names.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Z-plasty is a transposition flap technique that lengthens scars and releases contractures by creating and exchanging triangular flaps at specific angles, achieving 25-75% length gain.

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the newborn baby as shown in the image? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Imperforate anus

 

The given investigation is invertogram. It is done 6-12 hours after birth. It is done for anorectal malformations (ARM). Gap between the gas and coin measured, if it is >2 cm we suspect abnormalities proximal to pelvic floor, like rectal atresia (high ARM). If gap is < 2cm, the ARM is low, and restricted only to anal defects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meningocele is a type of neural tube defect that occurs during fetal development. It is attributed to the maternal folic acid deficiency. It involves protrusion of the meninges through a defect in the skull or vertebra. It is asymptomatic and mainly presents with a tuft of hair in the lumbosacral region.

 

Option B. Congenital Mega-colon is also known as Hirschsprung disease. It is congenital condition that occurs due to absence of ganglion cells in the colonic segment. The affected segment fails to relax, while the portion proximal to it becomes dilated.

 

Option D. Pyloric stenosis is a condition that affects the newborn and infants. It involves the hypertrophy of the pylorus leading to gastric outlet obstruction. The patient presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting with dehydration and hypochloremic hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An invertogram performed 6-12 hours after birth is used to diagnose anorectal malformations in newborns by measuring the distance between a gas bubble in the rectum and a coin marker on the perineum.

questions.text: Which of the following method is shown in the surgical procedure to close the abdominal wound with the help of a mesh? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Onlay

 

The image shows a mesh placed over the abdominal muscles to close a wound, which is indicative of the onlay method. In the onlay technique, the mesh is placed on top of the rectus sheath and anterior abdominal wall muscles. This is typically used in open ventral hernia repairs where the mesh is laid directly on top of the closed fascial layer. This method is chosen for its simplicity and effectiveness in reinforcing the abdominal wall from the outside.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sublay: In this method, the mesh is placed beneath the rectus muscles but above the peritoneum. It is also known as the retromuscular or sublay position. This is not the method shown in the image.

 

Option C. Inlay: This method involves placing the mesh between the edges of the defect without overlapping. This is generally used when the defect cannot be closed primarily. The image does not show this technique.

 

Option D. Intraperitoneal (Underlay): In this method, the mesh is placed inside the peritoneal cavity in direct contact with the abdominal organs. The image does not show this; instead, it shows the mesh being placed on top of the abdominal wall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The onlay method involves placing the mesh on top of the abdominal muscles and rectus sheath, commonly used in open ventral hernia repairs.

questions.text: Identify the level of amputation: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Below Knee

 

The correct answer is Below Knee amputation. In the provided image, the amputation level shows both the tibia and fibula bones, indicating that the amputation is below the knee. A below knee amputation preserves the knee joint, which is crucial for improved mobility and prosthetic fitting compared to an above knee amputation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Above Knee: In an above knee amputation, only the femur would be visible as the amputation occurs above the knee joint, which is not the case in the image provided.

 

Option C. Lis Franc: A Lis Franc amputation is a type of foot amputation that involves the tarsometatarsal joints.

 

Option D. Chopart: A Chopart amputation involves a disarticulation through the midfoot, specifically at the talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints. The image does not show the foot structures required for a Chopart amputation, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a below knee amputation, both the tibia and fibula bones are visible, distinguishing it from above knee and foot-level amputations like Lis Franc and Chopart.

questions.text: Name the material which is used for Lichtenstein mesh repair:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Polypropylene

 

The material used for Lichtenstein mesh repair is polypropylene, commonly referred to as Prolene mesh. It is a non-absorbable synthetic mesh, meaning it remains in the body permanently to provide ongoing support to the repaired area. The Lichtenstein repair technique is commonly used in hernia surgery to provide a tension-free repair by reinforcing the weakened area with this mesh.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyglycolic acid: This is incorrect because polyglycolic acid is an absorbable suture material and not suitable for long-term reinforcement as required in mesh repair.

 

Option C. Polyacrylamide: This is incorrect because polyacrylamide is not used in surgical mesh repairs.

 

Option D. Polygalactin: This is incorrect as polygalactin (Vicryl) is also an absorbable material used primarily for suturing, not for permanent mesh repair.

 

Extra edge:

 

In intraperitoneal repair, IPOM (Intraperitoneal onlay mesh), the mesh that you use is called a dual mesh or a composite mesh. So it will have proline on one side, it will have a collagen or a Teflon on the other side. So it has two surfaces, one surface facing upwards towards the peritoneum, one surface facing downwards towards the intestines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polypropylene mesh is the material of choice for Lichtenstein mesh repair due to its non-absorbable nature, providing long-term reinforcement for hernia repairs.

choices.text: Pelvic packing along with B/L percutaneous nephrostomy

questions.text: In a case of blunt abdominal trauma, a 30-year-old male patient presents with pelvic fracture, minimal urine output on catheterization, and no blood at the meatus. The radiological image shows extravasation of urine into the peritoneal cavity. What is the preferred next step in management? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laparotomy

 

The pattern of contrast extravasation in the given image suggests intraperitoneal bladder rupture, which is caused by a blow or fall on the distended bladder. The preferred next step of management, in this case, is laparotomy for repair and bladder drainage (suprapubic and urethral catheter). Hence, the correct option is C) Laparotomy. Laparoscopic approaches are also now being used.

 

Laparotomy is the preferred next step in management when a patient presents with of extravasation of urine into the peritoneal cavity (intra-peritoneal rupture), as it may lead to chemical peritonitis. This suggests a significant bladder injury, and a laparotomy is necessary to assess the extent of the injury and provide appropriate surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suprapubic cystostomy: Suprapubic cystostomy may be considered in cases of pelvic fracture and suspected urethral rupture. Absence of blood at urethral meatus rules out urethral rupture.

 

Option B. Perurethral catheterization: Perurethral catheterization may not be the best choice in this situation. It is preferred in extra-peritoneal ruptures.

 

Option D. Pelvic packing along with B/L percutaneous nephrostomy: Pelvic packing and percutaneous nephrostomy may be considered in certain cases of pelvic trauma but are not the primary management options when there is evidence of intraperitoneal bladder rupture.

questions.text: What is shown in the given image? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sebaceous cyst

 

The image provided shows a sebaceous cyst, with the characteristic black punctum.

 

  • Sebaceous cysts are common benign lumps that form under the skin due to blockade of sebaceous glands, causing a buildup of oil and skin cells.
  • The most common locations for sebaceous cysts are the face, neck, chest, and back especially postauricular sulcus or below and behind the ear lobule.
  • They typically appear as small, painless lumps that are round or oval in shape.
  • Treatment for sebaceous cysts involves surgical removal of the cyst. This is usually done under local anesthesia, and involves making a small elliptical incision in the skin and removing the cyst and its contents.
  • It is important to excise the cyst in its entirety as failure to do so usually results in recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermoid Cyst:

 

  • A dermoid cyst is a benign, slow-growing cystic lesion that can occur in various parts of the body, including the head and neck.
  • These cysts are often present from birth (congenital) and can contain a variety of tissues, including hair, teeth, and sometimes sebaceous (oil-producing) material.
  • Dermoid cysts are typically painless unless they become infected or inflamed.
  • Treatment involves surgical removal to prevent complications or for cosmetic reasons.

 

Option C. Meningioma:

 

  • A meningioma is a typically benign tumor that originates from the meninges, the membranes that cover the brain and spinal cord.
  • Meningiomas are slow-growing and may not cause symptoms initially.
  • When symptoms occur, they can include headaches, seizures, changes in vision or hearing, and neurological deficits.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed through imaging studies like MRI and CT scans, and treatment may involve surgery or radiation therapy depending on the tumor's location and size.

 

Option D. Postauricular Fistula:

 

  • A postauricular fistula, also known as a auricular sinus or pit, is a small hole or pit located in front of or behind the ear.
  • It is a congenital condition, meaning it is present from birth.
  • These pits can sometimes become infected, leading to symptoms like pain, swelling, and discharge.
  • Surgical removal may be considered if there are recurrent infections or other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sebaceous cysts are common benign lumps that form under the skin due to blockade of sebaceous glands, causing a buildup of oil and skin cells.

choices.text: Ask the mother to give high fiber diet
Plain X-ray of the abdomen
Barium enema and Anorectal manometry

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is suffering from constipation. Despite giving stool softeners the child is able to pass only one stool in a week. There is a history of delayed passage of meconium after 48 hours at birth. What initial management will you prescribe for this child? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Barium enema and Anorectal manometry

 

The history provided is suggestive of Hirschsprung’s disease, a condition characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon, leading to functional obstruction. This condition often presents in early childhood with symptoms of constipation and a history of delayed meconium passage.

 

  • Barium enema: This radiological test involves introducing barium contrast into the colon via the rectum, allowing visualization of the transition zone between the aganglionic (narrow) and ganglionic (dilated) segments of the colon, which is characteristic of Hirschsprung's disease.
  • Anorectal manometry: This test measures the pressures of the anal sphincter muscles and the neural reflexes necessary for normal bowel movements. In Hirschsprung's disease, the normal rectosphincteric reflex is absent.

 

These tests are critical for diagnosing Hirschsprung's disease. The investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis is a suction rectal biopsy showing aganglionosis.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Ask the mother to give high fiber diet:
    • Dietary fiber can help alleviate symptoms of constipation by bulking up stools and promoting regular bowel movements. However, in cases of Hirschsprung's disease, adding fiber might not be effective and can even exacerbate symptoms if there is a significant segment of the colon that is aganglionic (lacking nerve cells). This wouldn't be the first-line intervention in this context.
  • Option B. Plain X-ray of the abdomen:
    • An abdominal X-ray might show an obstruction or fecal loading, especially in the proximal (normal) portion of the bowel. However, it does not provide a specific diagnosis for Hirschsprung's disease and thus is not sufficient as the initial investigation.
  • Option D. Surgical treatment:
    • Surgical intervention is the definitive treatment for Hirschsprung's disease, involving the removal of the aganglionic segment of the bowel. However, this option is pursued after the diagnosis is confirmed and not as an initial approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Initial management of suspected Hirschsprung’s disease involves confirming the diagnosis with a Barium enema and Anorectal manometry.

 

Surgeries: Soave, Duhamel and Swenson procedures are done.

choices.text: Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected

questions.text: A female patient presents to the clinic with a painful lump in her breast that has been increasing in size over the past few days. After examination, the doctor diagnoses her with a breast abscess and prescribes antibiotics to help clear the infection. The doctor attempts to aspirate the abscess using a needle and syringe, but no fluid is obtained. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A second attempt at aspiration

 

Explanation:

 

If the first attempt at aspiration fails to obtain fluid, the next logical step is to attempt aspiration again, potentially with ultrasound guidance. Ultrasound guidance can enhance the accuracy of the procedure by allowing direct visualization of the abscess, ensuring that the needle is correctly positioned to access the abscess cavity. This method is less invasive than incision and drainage (I&D), making it a preferred option if it can effectively manage the abscess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incision and Drainage: Incision and drainage is generally considered if aspiration fails repeatedly or if the abscess is too large. While effective, it is not typically the immediate next step after a single failed aspiration attempt. It is more invasive than aspiration and usually reserved for cases where less invasive methods are unsuccessful.

 

Option B. Continue antibiotics only: Antibiotics are crucial in managing breast abscesses by treating the underlying infection. However, they alone might not suffice for large or dense abscesses. The pus trapped within the abscess often needs to be physically removed to expedite healing and provide symptom relief. Continuing antibiotics without addressing the abscess can lead to prolonged infection and discomfort.

 

Option D. Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected: This option is not recommended. The failure to collect aspirate does not imply the absence of infection. The antibiotics were prescribed based on the clinical diagnosis of a breast abscess, and stopping them prematurely could allow the infection to worsen. Continuation of antibiotics is important until the course is complete or unless indicated otherwise by a physician.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If the initial aspiration attempt for a breast abscess fails, the next step should be to attempt aspiration again, preferably under ultrasound guidance, before considering more invasive procedures like incision and drainage. This approach ensures accurate access to the abscess and minimizes invasiveness.

questions.text: A patient reports pain in the right upper abdomen. An ultrasound-guided FNAC of liver cysts reveals the presence of a parasitic organism. Which of the following is most likely to be the causative organism? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echinococcus granulosus

 

Echinococcus granulosus is the causative organism for hydatid cyst of the liver. The diagnosis is based on:

 

  • Location - Liver is the most common site for hydatid cysts
  • Imaging - Characteristic appearance on ultrasound
  • FNAC findings - Demonstrates scolices and hooklets of Echinococcus
  • Life cycle involves: 
    • Definitive host: Dog
    • Intermediate host: Sheep
    • Accidental host: Humans (dead end)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Taenia saginata : Incorrect. Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm) does not typically cause liver cysts. It mainly affects the intestine.

 

Option C. Taenia solium: Incorrect. Taenia solium (pork tapeworm) is associated with neurocysticercosis affecting the brain and muscles, not liver cysts.

 

Option D. H. nana: Incorrect. Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) is an intestinal parasite and does not cause liver cysts.

 

Educational Objective: 


Echinococcus granulosus is the causative organism for hydatid cysts of the liver, which is the most common site of hydatid disease.

choices.text: Gall bladder thickness >3 mm on USG
Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan

questions.text: 50-year-old obese female presents to the emergency department with severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, and nausea. The physician suspects acute cholecystitis and orders imaging studies to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following statements is not true about acute cholecystitis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan.

 

This statement is not true. In a Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid (HIDA) scan, the gallbladder is not preferentially visualized in acute cholecystitis. Instead, one of the hallmark findings in acute cholecystitis on a HIDA scan is non-visualization of the gallbladder due to inflammation and obstruction of the cystic duct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gall bladder thickness >3 mm on USG: This statement is true and is a common finding in acute cholecystitis. On ultrasound (USG), a thickened gallbladder wall, typically greater than 3 mm, is indicative of inflammation and is a characteristic feature of acute cholecystitis.

 

Option B. Murphy's sign positive: This statement is true. Murphy's sign is a clinical maneuver used to assess for acute cholecystitis. It involves palpation of the right upper quadrant during inspiration, and if the patient experiences pain or stops breathing due to pain during this maneuver, it is considered a positive Murphy's sign, suggesting inflammation of the gallbladder.

 

Option C. Leukocytosis: This statement is true. Acute cholecystitis is associated with an inflammatory response, leading to an elevation in white blood cell count, which is known as leukocytosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute cholecystitis is a common condition characterized by inflammation of the gallbladder, typically due to the presence of gallstones obstructing the cystic duct. Clinical features of acute cholecystitis include right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis. A positive Murphy's sign is right upper quadrant tenderness on palpation. On ultrasound imaging, gall bladder thickness >3 mm is a common finding in acute cholecystitis. The HIDA scan is a diagnostic tool for acute cholecystitis, showing non-visualization of the gall bladder 3 hours after radioisotope administration. Preferential visualization of the gall bladder on a HIDA scan is not a feature of acute cholecystitis. It is important to diagnose and treat acute cholecystitis promptly to prevent complications such as gallbladder perforation or gangrene.

questions.text: In a patient with renal stones, the following crystals suggest what etiology? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triple phosphate

 

The image provided in the question shows crystals that are described as "coffin-lid" shaped. These crystals are characteristic of triple phosphate stones, also known as struvite stones. Struvite stones are commonly associated with urinary tract infections caused by urease-producing bacteria, which raise the urine pH and promote the formation of these crystals.

 

  • Triple Phosphate Crystals (Struvite): These crystals have a distinctive coffin-lid shape, which is clearly depicted in the image. They are typically seen in alkaline urine and are associated with infections, especially those caused by urease-producing organisms like Proteus, Klebsiella, or Pseudomonas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uric Acid: Uric acid crystals are usually rhomboid or rosette-shaped. They form in acidic urine and are not associated with the coffin-lid appearance shown in the image.

 

Option C. Calcium Oxalate Monohydrate: These crystals have a dumbbell or ovoid shape, not resembling the coffin-lid appearance in the image.

 

Option D. Calcium Oxalate Dihydrate: These crystals are typically envelope-shaped, resembling a square with a diagonal cross. While they might be confused with the coffin-lid shape, they are distinctively different.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coffin-lid shaped crystals in a urine analysis are indicative of triple phosphate stones, commonly associated with urinary tract infections and alkaline urine.

choices.text: Prescribe an abdominal belt for the daily use
Advise observations and reassessment in 6 months

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient, who underwent midline laparotomy for colonic cancer one month ago, presents with a palpable abdominal bulge at the surgical site. Physical examination reveals a reducible midline incisional hernia of 12cm. What is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schedule for laparoscopic mesh repair 

 

For a patient with a palpable abdominal bulge at the site of a recent surgical incision, indicative of an incisional hernia, management options vary depending on the size of the hernia, symptoms, and the patient's overall health status. 

 

This is a minimally invasive approach that is commonly used for large ventral hernias like in this case. The use of mesh is associated with a lower rate of recurrence compared to suture repair alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prescribe an abdominal belt for daily use: While an abdominal belt or binder can provide temporary relief and support for a hernia, it does not correct the underlying issue. It is more of a conservative approach and may be considered in patients who are not candidates for surgery.

 

Option C. Advise observations and reassessment in 6 months: Observation may be appropriate for small, asymptomatic hernias or in patients where surgery poses a high risk. However, given the size of the hernia (12 cm), this approach could lead to an increased risk of complications such as incarceration or strangulation.

 

Option D. Laparoscopic closure without mesh: Closing the hernia laparoscopically without mesh is less favored for larger hernias due to higher recurrence rates compared to mesh repair.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The most appropriate next step in the management of a patient with a large, reducible midline incisional hernia is to schedule a laparoscopic mesh repair, which offers a minimally invasive approach with a lower risk of recurrence.

choices.text: Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis

questions.text: A 25-year-old male individual arrived at the emergency room following a road traffic accident, displaying signs indicative of a potential pelvic fracture. Upon assessment, he was determined to be experiencing hypovolemic shock. What is the initial course of action for managing hemorrhage control in this scenario? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis

 

In the immediate aftermath of a traumatic injury where a pelvic fracture is suspected, binding the pelvis with sheets (or commercial binders, if available) is a quick and effective way to provide temporary stabilization and reduce ongoing bleeding. This technique uses the concept of tamponading or compressing the bleeding vessels within the pelvis, which can be life-saving.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate internal fixation: This involves surgical stabilization of the pelvic fracture. While internal fixation might ultimately be necessary, it's not the initial action. Operating on an unstable patient can lead to further complications.

 

Option B. Multiple blood transfusions: Transfusing blood is critical for a patient in hypovolemic shock due to bleeding. However, it addresses the consequence (loss of blood) rather than the cause (active bleeding from the fracture). Stopping or controlling the bleed is paramount.

 

Option D. Emergency external fixation: External fixators can be applied to stabilize the pelvis and control hemorrhage. While this is a more definitive action than using bedsheets, it requires more time, equipment, and a surgical setting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Given the acute nature of the presentation and the need for immediate action to address life-threatening bleeding, the primary and fastest step would be C) Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis. This is a temporizing measure that can stabilize the patient until more definitive interventions (like external or internal fixation) can be safely undertaken.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with a history of cholecystectomy 4 years back for gallstones presents with symptoms of obstructive jaundice. Imaging studies reveal a stone in the common bile duct. What is the most probable type of stone causing this obstruction? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary  

 

The classification of common bile duct (CBD) stones helps determine the probable type and origin of the stones.

 

  • Primary bile duct stones, also known as primary choledocholithiasis, form directly within the bile duct. They are distinct from gallbladder stones.
  • Their formation is typically associated with bile stasis, infection, or parasitic infestation of the bile ducts, particularly the liver fluke Clonorchis sinensis, which is endemic in some parts of Asia.
  •  These stones are often pigmented.
  •  The fact that this patient developed a stone in the common bile duct following a cholecystectomy >2 years back suggests the stone might be a primary stone, forming due to some underlying bile duct pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Secondary: Secondary bile duct stones, or secondary choledocholithiasis, refer to gallstones that formed in the gallbladder and then migrated into the bile duct. This is the most common cause of bile duct stones in patients who still have their gallbladders. Secondary stones are typically cholesterol stones, being yellowish and softer than primary stones.

 

Option C. Tertiary: Tertiary stones are essentially advanced secondary stones. They are stones that have resided in the ductal system for a long time after migrating from the gallbladder, and over time, they might undergo changes due to recurrent bouts of cholangitis or prolonged bile stasis.

 

Option D. Retained: Retained stones refer to stones that were overlooked or missed during an initial procedure, like a cholecystectomy. They should be diagnosed within 2 years of cholecystectomy. They remain in the bile duct and can later cause symptoms. These stones were originally in the gallbladder or bile duct at the time of surgery and were not adequately removed or were missed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Primary bile duct stones form directly within the bile ducts and are associated with underlying bile duct pathology.
  • They are different from secondary stones, which form in the gallbladder and migrate into the bile duct, and retained stones, which are missed during the initial surgery.

questions.text:
What procedures are carried out during Breast Conservation Surgery? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Wide local excision
  2. Axillary node dissection
  3. Frozen section (biopsy) to be done during surgery
  4. Post-operative radiotherapy is optional
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

 

1. Wide local excision:

 

  • This involves the removal of the breast tumor and a margin of surrounding normal tissue. The goal is to ensure that no cancer cells remain at the site, while preserving as much of the breast's appearance and function as possible.

 

2. Axillary node dissection:

 

  • This procedure involves removing lymph nodes from the axilla to check for the spread of cancer. If the sentinel lymph node biopsy (a procedure to remove the first node(s) that breast cancer is likely to spread) shows cancer, more extensive lymph node surgery might be done.

 

3. Frozen section (biopsy) to be done during surgery:

 

  • A frozen section involves rapidly freezing a tissue sample from the patient during surgery. A pathologist then examines the tissue under a microscope. This procedure allows for an immediate diagnosis, which can guide surgical decisions during the procedure, such as whether wider excision is needed if margins are not clear.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Post-operative radiotherapy is optional:

 

  • This statement is incorrect in the context of Breast Conservation Surgery (BCS). Post-operative radiotherapy is essential after BCS to reduce the risk of local recurrence of the tumor in the preserved breast tissue. It is not optional; rather, it's a standard part of the treatment plan in most cases.

 

Breast Conservative Therapy (BCT) consists of:

 

a. Wide local excision (>1cm) of tumor

 

b. Sentinel lymph node biopsy (if clinically node negative)

 

c. Post-operative radiotherapy given in all cases of BCT

 

d. If pre-operative axillary LN metastasis is present, no need for sentinel lymph node biopsy. Up front axillary lymphadenectomy is done along with wide local excision of tumor.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents to the ER with a history of trauma two weeks back with confusion and ataxia. CT scan reveals the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subdural haemorrhage

 

  • The given clinical scenario and the plain CT scan is suggestive of subdural hematoma (SDH).
  • Subdural hematomas typically occur due to the rupture of bridging veins, which can be associated with mild trauma, cerebral atrophy, elderly age, or chronic alcohol overuse.
  •  The presentation of symptoms like confusion and ataxia two weeks after trauma is characteristic of a chronic subdural hematoma.

 

Subdural Hematoma (SDH)

 

  • Pathology: Rupture of bridging veins.
  • Etiology: Can be acute (traumatic) or chronic (associated with mild trauma, cerebral atrophy, elderly age, chronic alcohol overuse). Also seen in shaken babies.
  • Clinical Features: Typically presents without a lucid interval; altered consciousness from the onset. Features of raised intracranial tension and neurological deficits may be present.
  • CT Findings: Crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extradural Hemorrhage

 

  • Pathology: Rupture of the middle meningeal artery (branch of the maxillary artery), often secondary to a skull fracture involving the pterion.
  • Clinical Features: Often includes a lucid interval (period of normalcy between two periods of unconsciousness).
  • CT Findings: Biconvex (lentiform), hyperdense blood collection that does not cross suture lines.

 

Option C. Intra-parenchymal Hemorrhage

 

  • Pathology: Most commonly caused by systemic hypertension.
  • Location: Most often occurs in the putamen/globus pallidus of the basal ganglia (lenticulostriate vessels).
  • CT Findings: Intra-parenchymal bleed.

 

Option D. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage

 

  • Pathology: Bleeding due to trauma or rupture of an aneurysm (such as a saccular aneurysm).
  • Clinical Features: Patients complain of the worst headache of my life. Bloody or yellow lumbar puncture. Vasospasm can occur, nimodipine is used to prevent/reduce it.
  • CT Findings: Intraventricular and subarachnoid space hyperdensities represent acute hemorrhages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Subdural hematoma typically results from the rupture of bridging veins and presents without a lucid interval.
  •  CT scans of subdural hematoma show a crescent-shaped hemorrhage that crosses suture lines.

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect finding in Mirizzi syndrome? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Hemobilia

 

Explanation:

 

Mirizzi syndrome occurs when a gallstone becomes impacted in the cystic duct or neck of the gallbladder, causing inflammation and extrinsic compression of the common hepatic duct. This mechanical obstruction leads to obstructive jaundice. Hemobilia (bleeding into the biliary tract) is not a feature of Mirizzi syndrome but rather a distinct pathology typically seen after liver trauma, vascular malformations, or biliary procedures, where erosion of a blood vessel leads to bleeding into the biliary tree.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Jaundice - This is a correct feature of Mirizzi syndrome. Patients present with obstructive jaundice due to the mechanical compression of the common hepatic duct, resulting in the classic triad of jaundice, pruritis, and clay-colored stools.

 

Option B. Cystic duct obstruction - This is a correct feature of Mirizzi syndrome. The pathophysiology begins with a stone becoming impacted in the cystic duct or gallbladder neck, causing obstruction and surrounding inflammation that then affects nearby structures.

 

Option C. Cholecystocholedochal fistula - This is a correct feature seen in progressive Mirizzi syndrome. The Csendes classification describes how the impacted stone can erode through the wall of the cystic duct into the common hepatic duct, creating a fistula that may involve varying degrees of the duct circumference (Types 2-4).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mirizzi syndrome involves obstructive jaundice caused by extrinsic compression of the common hepatic duct by gallstones impacted in the cystic duct, potentially leading to fistula formation, but does not involve bleeding into the biliary tree (hemobilia).

choices.text: Repeated radical surgery every 24 hours may be required to adequately manage this condition
This is a case of Meleney's gangrene
The condition is caused by beta Hemolytic streptococcus and may sometimes be polymicrobial
Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false about the given condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition

 

  • The image depicts necrotizing fasciitis of the abdominal wall, also known as Meleney's gangrene.
  • This condition is a severe soft tissue infection characterized by rapidly spreading inflammation and necrosis.
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy has been shown to have some benefit in managing this condition.

 

Meleney's Gangrene (Necrotizing Fasciitis)

 

  • Clinical Features: Signs of local inflammation, skin gangrene, and features of septicemia such as hypotension and fever.
  • Investigation: Culture swab tests usually reveal aerobes (such as beta-hemolytic Streptococci) and anaerobes, making the condition often polymicrobial.
  • Treatment:
    • Surgical: Radical wide debridement is necessary and may need to be repeated every 24-48 hours to manage the infection effectively.
    • Medical: Intravenous antibiotics are critical to treating the infection.
    • Adjunctive Therapy: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy has some benefits and is used as an adjunct in the management of necrotizing fasciitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeated radical surgery every 24 hours may be required to adequately manage this condition: True: Radical wide debridement is often needed repeatedly (every 24-48 hours) to control the spread of the infection and remove necrotic tissue.

 

Option B. This is a case of Meleney's gangrene: True: The condition shown in the image is Meleney's gangrene, a specific form of necrotizing fasciitis.

 

Option C. The condition is caused by beta Hemolytic streptococcus and may sometimes be polymicrobial: True: The infection can be caused by beta-hemolytic Streptococci and is often polymicrobial, involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meleney's gangrene, or necrotizing fasciitis, requires aggressive surgical debridement, intravenous antibiotics, and may benefit from adjunctive hyperbaric oxygen therapy.
  • The condition is often polymicrobial, involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

questions.text: Match the surgery with related nerve injuries: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

 

 

The following are the associations between the type of surgery and the nerve most commonly at risk of injury:

 

A. Breast surgery - Long Thoracic Nerve: The Long Thoracic Nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which anchors the scapula to the chest wall. Injury to this nerve during breast surgery, especially radical mastectomies where axillary lymph nodes are removed, can lead to a condition called "winged scapula," where the medial border of the scapula protrudes outwards.

 

B. Thyroid surgery - External Laryngeal nerve: The External Laryngeal nerve is a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (itself a branch of the vagus nerve). It supplies the cricothyroid muscle, which plays a role in tensioning the vocal cords. Injury during thyroid surgery can lead to voice changes, particularly affecting the pitch.

 

C. Submandibular excision - Hypoglossal nerve: The Hypoglossal nerve is the twelfth cranial nerve and supplies the muscles of the tongue. Injury to this nerve during excision of the submandibular gland can lead to tongue deviation towards the side of the injury due to the unopposed action of the tongue muscles on the unaffected side.

 

D. Thymectomy - Vagus nerve: The Vagus nerve, or the tenth cranial nerve, has a wide range of functions including supplying parasympathetic fibers to many organs in the thorax and abdomen. Injury during thymectomy, a surgical procedure to can have multiple effects, including voice changes due to its role in innervating the larynx. However, it's worth noting that the phrenic nerve, which innervates the diaphragm, is also at risk during a thymectomy.

 

In summary, during surgical procedures, it's imperative to be aware of the nearby nerves and their courses to prevent unintended nerve injury, as this can lead to significant postoperative complications

choices.text: Visible peristalsis from left to right

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which among the following will not be seen in this child? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bilious vomiting

 

In congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, the hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pylorus muscle lead to gastric outlet obstruction. This causes projectile, non-bilious vomiting because the obstruction is proximal to the bile duct entry into the duodenum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Visible peristalsis from left to right: Due to the obstruction caused by CHPS, there's an increase in gastric peristalsis as the stomach tries to push its contents past the hypertrophied pylorus. This can result in visible waves of peristalsis moving from the left side of the abdomen (where the stomach is located) to the right side (towards the pylorus) on giving a feed.

 

Option C. Hypochloremia and hypokalemia: Persistent vomiting in CHPS can lead to the loss of gastric acid (hydrochloric acid). This results in hypochloremia due to the loss of chloride ions. The body also tries to compensate for the alkalosis by excreting more potassium in the kidneys, leading to hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis: As mentioned earlier, the loss of gastric acid from repeated vomiting results in a state of metabolic alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CHPS (congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis) is most commonly seen in infants between 2 to 8 weeks of age.
  • It is caused by the hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the Pylorus, which results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet.
  • First-born male infants are at the highest risk for developing CHPS.
  • Projectile, non-bilious vomiting is a common symptom in infants with CHPS.
  • A palpable olive-shaped mass is usually felt in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium, and visible peristalsis can be observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting.
  • Infants with CHPS develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality including hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.
  • Loss of hydrochloric acid leads to metabolic alkalosis and hypochloremia due to persistent vomiting.
  • The kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3, but the loss of sodium stimulates aldosterone secretion leading to the loss of potassium ions (hypokalemia).
  • Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in paradoxical aciduria.
  • Treatment involves rehydration and correction of metabolic abnormalities before surgery, and the Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for CHPS.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with a long-standing history of recurrent abdominal pain, nausea, and steatorrhea. The patient reports a significant history of alcohol abuse, and diagnostic imaging reveals signs of chronic pancreatitis. What is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Alcohol

 

Chronic alcohol consumption is the leading cause of chronic pancreatitis. Excessive alcohol intake can lead to repeated episodes of acute pancreatitis, eventually resulting in chronic inflammation, fibrosis, and loss of pancreatic function. Alcohol-induced chronic pancreatitis often presents with pain, malabsorption (leading to steatorrhea), and diabetes mellitus due to the destruction of insulin-producing cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gallstones: When they travel out of the gallbladder into the bile ducts, they can block the pancreatic duct, leading to inflammation of the pancreas, termed acute pancreatitis. While gallstones are a common cause of acute pancreatitis, they are not the predominant cause of chronic pancreatitis.

 

Option C. Autoimmune: Autoimmune pancreatitis (AIP) is a type of chronic pancreatitis caused by an autoimmune reaction against the pancreatic tissue. It can be part of the spectrum of IgG4-related disease. The pancreas may become enlarged and look like a tumor on imaging studies. AIP might present with jaundice, weight loss, and the aforementioned pancreatic enlargement. Treatment usually involves corticosteroids to suppress the immune response.

 

Option D. Drugs: Some drugs are known to cause pancreatitis. While the incidence is generally low, drug-induced pancreatitis can turn chronic if the offending medication isn't identified and discontinued. Common culprits include diuretics like furosemide and thiazides, certain antiretroviral drugs, and some antiepileptics like valproic acid, among others.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic alcohol consumption is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis, leading to repeated inflammation, fibrosis, and loss of pancreatic function over time.

choices.text: Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm
Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery
Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is > 70mm

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient, during his routine annual checkup, is found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 40 mm in diameter on USG abdomen. Which of the following is true about the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm

 

Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm: True. Generally, surgery (either open surgical repair or EVAR) is recommended for asymptomatic male patients when the AAA reaches a diameter of 5.5 cm (55mm) or greater. The risk of rupture increases significantly as the diameter surpasses this threshold, so this is the currently accepted cutoff for intervention in many guidelines.

 

Surgery is indicated in asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm only if its diameter is more than 55mm.

 

If the diameter is less than 55mm, regular ultrasound monitoring is required. This is because elective open surgery has a higher rate of mortality when compared to conservative management for aneurysms of size <55mm.

 

Other Options:

 

The size of an AAA determines the risk of rupture, and this risk informs the decision for surgical intervention.

 

Option A. Urgent endovascular aneurysm repair: Not necessarily true for a 40mm AAA. Endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) is a less invasive method than open surgery, but it is not typically done urgently for aneurysms of this size unless they are symptomatic or rapidly increasing in size.

 

Option C. Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery: Not true for a 40mm AAA. As the aneurysm is still below the general threshold for surgical intervention, there's no need for urgent operation unless there are other complicating factors (e.g., rapid growth or symptoms).

 

Option D. Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is >70mm: Not true. Waiting for an AAA to reach 70mm before considering surgery would expose the patient to a very high risk of rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgery (open surgical repair or EVAR) is recommended for asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysms when the diameter reaches 55mm or greater due to the increased risk of rupture beyond this size. Regular monitoring is advised for smaller aneurysms.

questions.text: A surgeon performs an appendicectomy with a grid iron incision. He later converts the incision to Rutherford Morrison incision. Which of the following are cut? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

When the initial Gridiron incision is converted to Rutherford Morrison incision, the external oblique, internal oblique, and transverse abdominis muscles are cut.

 

Gridiron incision is also known as McArthurs incision. It is a muscle splitting incision used in open appendicectomy.

 

Rutherford Morrison incision is useful in cases where the appendix is para- or retrocaecal and fixed. The lower end of the incision is located over McBurney's point and extends obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary. It involves cutting through the skin, subcutaneous tissues, external oblique, underlying internal oblique, transversus abdominis, and peritoneum along the line of the incision.

 

The Lanz incision is a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis, located 2 cm below the umbilicus and centered on the midclavicular-mid-inguinal line.

 

The Pfannenstiel incision is an infraumbilical transverse incision in the lower abdomen, often used for gynecological and obstetric procedures.

questions.text: In a patient at risk of re-feeding syndrome, which of the following electrolyte imbalances is typically not associated with this condition? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperkalemia 

 

Unlike hypokalemia, hyperkalemia is not typically associated with re-feeding syndrome. Instead, rapid re-feeding may lead to increased insulin secretion, which drives potassium into cells, potentially causing hypokalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypokalemia: Re-feeding syndrome can lead to hypokalemia due to increased cellular uptake of potassium during the anabolic phase, especially if there is concomitant insulin administration.

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: Re-feeding syndrome can cause hypocalcemia due to decreased parathyroid hormone secretion and subsequent impaired bone resorption, leading to low serum calcium levels.

 

Option D. Hypophosphatemia: Re-feeding syndrome is characterized by rapid shifts of phosphate into cells during the anabolic phase, leading to hypophosphatemia, which can manifest clinically as weakness, respiratory failure, and arrhythmias.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In patients at risk of re-feeding syndrome, electrolyte imbalances such as hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, and hypophosphatemia are commonly observed, while hyperkalemia is typically not associated with this condition.

questions.text: During total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, which of the following steps will not lead to hoarseness of voice?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dissection of strap muscles

 

Hoarseness of voice after thyroidectomy is generally due to injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), which controls the vocal cords. The RLN is located near the thyroid gland, and careful surgical technique is necessary to avoid damaging it. The strap muscles, which are located anterior to the thyroid gland, are far from the path of the RLN, so dissecting these muscles will not result in hoarseness of voice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option  A. Dissection of Beahrs triangle: The recurrent laryngeal nerve forms the anterior boundary of Beahrs triangle, making it susceptible to injury during dissection, which can lead to hoarseness.

 

Option B. Dissection of Zuckerkandl tubercle: The Zuckerkandl tubercle is closely associated with the recurrent laryngeal nerve, so dissection in this area can risk nerve injury and subsequent hoarseness.

 

Option D. Ligation of Superior thyroid artery: This procedure is generally more likely to affect the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve rather than the recurrent laryngeal nerve, but in cases of anatomical variation, there is a small risk that the RLN could be affected, potentially leading to hoarseness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dissection of the strap muscles during thyroidectomy does not involve the recurrent laryngeal nerve, and therefore, will not cause hoarseness of voice.

choices.text: Patent Vitello intestinal duct
Patent umbilical end of the omphalomesenteric duct

questions.text: A 5-day old baby is passing greenish-yellow fecal discharge from the umbilicus. What could be the embryological cause of this condition? (FMGE DECEMEBR 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Patent Vitello intestinal duct

 

The condition described, where a 5-day old baby is passing greenish-yellow fecal discharge from the umbilicus, suggests an abnormal connection between the intestine and the umbilicus. The most likely cause is a patent Vitello-intestinal duct, also known as a persistent omphalomesenteric duct. This duct normally obliterates during fetal development, but if it remains patent, it can result in fecal matter being discharged through the umbilicus.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Patent Allantois:
    • The allantois is an embryonic structure involved in early fluid exchange between the embryo and the yolk sac. If it remains patent, it typically leads to a urachal fistula, which causes urine, not fecal discharge, to pass from the umbilicus.
  • Option C. Meckel’s diverticulum:
    • Meckel’s diverticulum is a remnant of the vitello-intestinal duct that forms a small pouch on the intestine, usually the ileum. While it can cause complications such as bleeding, obstruction, or inflammation, it does not cause fecal discharge from the umbilicus.
  • Option D. Patent umbilical end of the omphalomesenteric duct:
    • If only the umbilical end of the duct remains open, it can lead to an umbilical sinus, which might produce some mucus or serous discharge but typically not fecal discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A patent Vitello-intestinal duct can lead to the passage of fecal matter from the umbilicus in newborns.

questions.text: Which of these classifications of bile duct injury takes into account the location of injury, and thermal and vascular injury to bile ducts? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hannover 

 

  • When discussing bile duct injuries, several classification systems have been developed to categorize these injuries based on their nature, location, and the extent of damage. 

 

This system categorizes bile duct injuries based on the anatomical structure involved and the extent of the injury, including vascular injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bismuth Classification: Primarily focuses on the location of the bile duct injury in relation to the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts. This classification is widely used to describe bile duct injuries post-cholecystectomy.

 

Option B. Strassberg Classification (also known as the Strassberg-Bismuth classification): This is an extension of the Bismuth classification, adding more detail and incorporating the critical view of safety concept. It includes acute injuries, but it is based on location alone. Associated vascular injuries are not included.

 

Option C. Stewart-Way Classification: This classification focuses on the phase of the operation in which the injury occurs and the type of injury, including thermal damage. It categorizes injuries into four types:

 

  1. Type I: Cystic duct leak or leakage from a small peripheral hepatic radicle close to the gallbladder fossa.
  2. Type II: Injury to the main bile duct that does not involve excision, typically a lateral injury.
  3. Type III: Complete transaction or excision of a segment of the main bile duct.
  4. Type IV: Injury involving damage to the hepatic duct confluence and bifurcation.

 

Stewart-Way classification does not account for associated vascular injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bismuth and Strassberg classifications are anatomically based classifications of bile duct injury.

questions.text: Identify the modality shown in the image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retrograde pyelogram

 

The X-ray shows characteristics of retrograde pyelogram:

 

  • Contrast visible in only one ureter and renal pelvis
  • Presence of catheter visible (placed via cystoscopy)
  • No nephrogram phase visible (kidney shadow not seen)
  • Shows renal pelvis in claw-like appearance
  • Performed by injecting contrast directly into ureter via cystoscopy
  • Used when IVU fails or in non-functioning kidney

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IVU: Incorrect as IVU shows bilateral ureter and renal system, includes nephrogram phase, and no catheter is visible

 

 

Option C. Ureteric stent: Incorrect as a stent would appear as a distinct radio-opaque tube with curved ends (double-J appearance), without contrast
 

 

Option D. Nephrostomy tube: Incorrect as nephrostomy tube enters directly through flank into kidney, not via ureter

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Retrograde Pyelogram (RGP) is a contrast study performed via cystoscopy, allowing visualization of one-sided ureters and renal pelvis. It is used to diagnose ureteric strictures, stones, and tumors.

choices.text: Repair with great saphenous vein graft

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient arrives at the emergency department with a history of stabbing injury to her arm. Upon examination, there is a noticeable hematoma, and the patient reports not feeling any radial or ulnar pulses in the affected arm. Imaging reveals a 3cm longitudinal tear in the brachial artery. The medical team is faced with deciding the best treatment option for the patient. Which option should they choose? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Repair with great saphenous vein graft

 

  • The preferred treatment option for a patient with an injury to the brachial artery caused by a stab injury is to repair it with a great saphenous vein graft harvested from the patient's uninjured leg.
  • Repairing vessel injuries requires a tension-free approach.
  • The great saphenous vein is the most desirable graft for interposition grafts because of its elastic properties, similar diameter to that of an extremity artery, lack of thrombogenicity, and long-term patency.
  • Other graft materials that can be used include the cephalic vein, lesser saphenous vein, and prosthetic conduits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary repair with end-to-end anastomosis: Primary arterial repair with end-to-end anastomosis is only possible if the repair can be performed in a tension-free manner. If the injured area is too long, an interposition graft is required.

 

Option C. Repair with prosthetic graft: Prosthetic grafts are only preferred when the native saphenous vein has been traumatized or when there is a size mismatch. Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) graft is commonly used as a prosthetic conduit.

 

Option D. Repair with saphenous vein patch: Saphenous vein patch is used for the closure of arteriotomy site during carotid endarterectomies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Repair with a great saphenous vein graft is an appropriate choice in cases of brachial artery injury with extensive damage and vascular compromise, allowing for the restoration of blood flow to the arm. This surgical intervention should be performed urgently to prevent further ischemic complications in the affected limb.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and jaundice. Upon evaluation, an ultrasound of the abdomen was performed. Based on the image provided, which structure likely represents a choledochal cyst? Identify the choledochal cyst in the image below? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type III

 

The image depicts a choledochocele, which is a Type III choledochal cyst. Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the biliary ducts and are more common in females. These cysts can lead to recurrent abdominal pain and jaundice due to bile duct obstruction.

 

  • Type I (MC): Dilation of the extrahepatic biliary tree.
    • Type Ia: Cystic dilation (most common type).
    • Type Ib: Focal segmental dilation.
    • Type Ic: Fusiform dilation.
  • Type II: Diverticular dilation of the extrahepatic biliary tree.
  • Type III: Cystic dilation of the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct, known as choledochocele.
  • Type IVA: Dilation of both the extrahepatic and intrahepatic biliary tree.
  • Type IVB: Dilation of multiple sections of the extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type V: Dilation confined to the intrahepatic bile ducts, also known as Carolis disease.
  • Type VI: Cystic dilation of the cystic duct (not included in Todanis modification).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I: Represents dilation of the extrahepatic biliary tree. It is the most common type but does not correspond to the image provided.

 

Option C. Type IV: Involves dilation of both intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. The image does not show such extensive dilation.

 

Option D. Type V: Known as Caroli's disease, involves dilation confined to the intrahepatic bile ducts, which is not depicted in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Choledochal cysts are classified into several types based on the location and nature of the biliary dilation. Type III choledochal cysts, or choledochocele, involve cystic dilation of the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with painless, massive lower gastrointestinal bleeding. He is diagnosed with Meckel's diverticulum, and surgical treatment is planned. Which of the following is the most commonly encountered ectopic tissue in Meckel's diverticulum? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gastric and pancreatic

 

Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital anomaly caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct during gestation. The rule of 2s mnemonic for Meckel's diverticulum includes 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric and pancreatic), located within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve, approximately 2 inches in length, and with a 2% incidence.

 

Meckel's diverticulum can present with painless, massive lower gastrointestinal bleeding, and it can be a lead point for ileoileal or ileocolic intussusception. Diagnosis is confirmed with a 99mTc-pertechnetate isotope scan to detect gastric mucosa and pancreatic tissue.

 

Surgical treatment is the definitive therapy for Meckel's diverticulum, and V-shaped diverticulectomy with transverse closure of the ileum is commonly performed.

questions.text: Image a of child with an orofacial cleft as shown. When is the first repair done? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 months

 

The initial repair for cleft lip is typically performed at around 3 months of age. According to Millard's Rule of 10, the surgery is ideally done when the infant is at least 10 weeks old, weighs around 10 pounds (approximately 4.5 kilograms), and has a hemoglobin level of 10 grams per deciliter. This timing helps ensure the child is sufficiently mature and robust for surgery, minimizing surgical risks and optimizing healing.

 

Repair of the cleft lip/nose and anterior palate generally occurs between 3 to 6 months of age, while definitive repair of the cleft palate is typically performed between 6 and 12 months of age, as outlined in the provided reference.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6 months: This is the general timeframe for repairing the soft palate but is not the earliest repair. For cleft lip, the first repair usually happens earlier, at around 3 months.

 

Option C. 12 months: This is more appropriate for the repair of the hard palate and definitive palate repair, not the initial cleft lip repair.

 

Option D. 2 years: This timing is not typically relevant for the first repair of cleft lip or palate and is much later than the standard recommendations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first repair of cleft lip is typically done at around 3 months of age, following the Millard's Rule of 10, to optimize surgical outcomes and ensure the infant is prepared for the procedure.

questions.text: According to the Muir and Barclay resuscitation protocol, which of the following colloids is recommended for use? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Albumin

 

The Muir and Barclay formula is a colloid-based burn resuscitation protocol that specifically uses human albumin as the colloid of choice. 

 

This formula calculates fluid requirements as: 

 

(% TBSA burn body weight in kg) / 2 = volume of colloid per period. 

 

The resuscitation is divided into three periods of 4, 4, and 6 hours in the first 24 hours, then continuing periods thereafter. 

 

Unlike the Parkland formula which uses crystalloids (Ringer's lactate) exclusively in the first 24 hours, Muir and Barclay incorporates albumin from the beginning to maintain oncotic pressure and reduce edema formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PRBC: Incorrect. Packed Red Blood Cells are blood products used for replacing blood loss and treating anemia, not routine colloid resuscitation in burns. They are reserved for significant blood loss or severe anemia.

 

Option B. FFP: Incorrect. Fresh Frozen Plasma is used for coagulopathy correction and contains clotting factors. It is not the standard colloid in burn resuscitation formulas and would only be used if coagulation abnormalities develop.

 

Option D. Dextran: Incorrect. Although dextran is a synthetic colloid, it is rarely used in modern burn resuscitation due to potential complications including coagulopathy and anaphylactic reactions. Clinical practice has largely abandoned its use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Muir and Barclay formula uses human albumin as the colloid for burn resuscitation, calculated as (% TBSA weight in kg)/2 per time period.

choices.text: Insulinoma; cystic duct, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum
Gastrinoma; CBD, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum
Gastrinoma; cystic duct, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum
Insulinoma; CBD, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum

questions.text: A patient with a history of peptic ulcer shows increased gastrin levels upon pentagastrin stimulation. What is the probable diagnosis and its anatomical boundaries? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gastrinoma; cystic duct, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum


The clinical presentation and elevated gastrin levels indicate Gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome). The anatomical area where gastrinomas are commonly found is called the Triangle of Passaro, which is bounded by:

 

  • Cystic duct superiorly
  • Second and third parts of duodenum medially
  • Head and neck of pancreas forming the third boundary.
  • Most common location within this triangle is the duodenum. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by:
    • Elevated fasting serum gastrin
    • Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS) shows 100% positivity

 

 

Other Options:
