Option A. Insulinoma; cystic duct, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum: Incorrect. Insulinoma presents with Whipple's triad and hypoglycemia, not elevated gastrin levels.

 

Option B. Gastrinoma; CBD, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum: Incorrect. While gastrinoma is correct, the CBD is not the correct anatomical boundary - it's the cystic duct.

 

Option D. Insulinoma; CBD, 2nd & 3rd part of the duodenum: Incorrect. Neither the diagnosis (insulinoma) nor the anatomical boundary (CBD) is correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrinoma occurs within the Triangle of Passaro, bounded by the cystic duct, 2nd and 3rd parts of duodenum, and head/neck of pancreas, with duodenum being the most common location.

 

Gastrinoma

 

  • Malignant
  • Present in triangle of passaro
  • MC site: duodenum (D1)

 

 

Clinical feature: due to hypergastrinemia Zollinger ellison syndrome

 

  1. Recurrent peptic ulcer
  2. Ulcer at abnormal location
  3. Acid induced diarrhea

questions.text: The Ripstein procedure is done for: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Rectal prolapse

 

Explanation:

 

The Ripstein procedure is a type of abdominal rectopexy used specifically for treating full-thickness rectal prolapse. It involves placing a mesh anterior to the rectum like a sling and fixing it to the sacrum behind. This technique suspends the rectum and prevents prolapse, though it has more post-operative complications due to its sling effect compared to other rectopexy methods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hirschsprung disease - This is treated with pull-through procedures (Swenson, Duhamel, or Soave) which resect the aganglionic segment and create a colo-anal anastomosis, not with rectopexy.

 

Option C. Hemorrhoids - These are treated with different procedures including banding, sclerotherapy, hemorrhoidectomy (Milligan-Morgan or Ferguson), stapled hemorrhoidopexy, or newer techniques like Doppler-guided hemorrhoidal artery ligation.

 

Option D. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis - This condition requires Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy, which involves cutting the pyloric muscle along its length while preserving the mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ripstein rectopexy uses a mesh sling placed anterior to the rectum for full-thickness rectal prolapse, but has higher post-operative constipation rates compared to other rectopexy techniques like Well's procedure.

choices.text: Palpable abdominal lump is the earliest sign
Clinical presentation of gall stones can sometimes be distinguished from gall bladder cancer
Median age of survival is 6 months in all cases

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents to the hospital with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. She was diagnosed with cholecystitis and cholelithiasis and underwent cholecystectomy. The post-operative biopsy reports came back positive for gallbladder carcinoma. What is true about gallbladder carcinoma? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clinical presentation of gall stones can sometimes be distinguished from gall bladder cancer

 

This statement is correct. The clinical presentation of gallstones (cholelithiasis) and gallbladder cancer (carcinoma) can sometimes be distinguished. Gallstones commonly cause symptoms such as biliary colic (episodic, severe right upper quadrant pain) and may lead to acute cholecystitis, which includes symptoms like pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. In contrast, gallbladder carcinoma may present with more persistent or progressive symptoms, including unexplained weight loss and, in some cases, a palpable abdominal mass. The two conditions can have overlapping symptoms, but their clinical courses can be distinguished based on the duration and progression of symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palpable abdominal lump is the earliest sign: This statement is not true. A palpable abdominal lump is not typically the earliest sign of gallbladder carcinoma. Gallbladder carcinoma often presents with nonspecific symptoms such as right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. As the cancer progresses, it may cause other symptoms, but a palpable lump is usually a late finding.

 

Option B. Earliest sign is jaundice: This statement is also not true for most cases of gallbladder carcinoma. Jaundice is more commonly associated with cancers of the bile ducts (cholangiocarcinoma) or pancreatic cancer when the tumor obstructs the bile ducts. While gallbladder carcinoma can cause jaundice if it obstructs the common bile duct, it is not typically the earliest sign of the disease.

 

Option D. Median age of survival is 6 months: This statement is not accurate for all cases of gallbladder carcinoma. The survival rate for gallbladder carcinoma can vary widely depending on factors such as the stage at diagnosis and the extent of surgical resection. While some cases have a poor prognosis with a short median survival, others may have a better outcome if diagnosed at an earlier stage and treated appropriately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Option C is correct because gallstones and gallbladder carcinoma often have distinct clinical presentations, allowing them to be distinguished from each other.

choices.text: From the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum.
From the angle of the mouth to the tragus to the xiphisternum.
From the ala of the nose to the angle of the mandible to the xiphisternum.
From the angle of the mouth to the ear lobule to the umbilicus

questions.text: What is the appropriate technique to measure the placement of a nasogastric tube? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) From the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum.

 

This is the correct method. The nasogastric tube length is usually measured by estimating the distance from the tip of the nose, past the ear lobule (or the earlobe), and down to the xiphisternum (the point where the sternum meets the costal margin), also known as N-E-X rule. This method ensures that the tube is long enough to pass through the esophagus and reach the stomach without being too long to cause complications or too short to not be effective.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

To determine the appropriate length of a nasogastric tube (also known as Ryle's tube) used for treating intestinal obstruction or providing nutritional support, the NEX method is commonly used, which involves measuring from the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum. The approximate length to be inserted is around 55 cm. The preferred position for inserting the Ryle's tube is in a sitting position with the neck slightly flexed.

 

The proper positioning of the tube can be confirmed through auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air or by an abdominal radiograph. The ideal placement for an NG tube used for suction is within the stomach to avoid damage to the duodenum. In contrast, an NG feeding tube should be placed post-pyloric to reduce the risk of aspiration.

 

Indications for NG tube usage include gastric decompression in intestinal obstruction, aspiration of gastric fluid, nutritional support, and medication administration. However, some absolute contraindications to NG tube insertion include severe midface trauma and recent nasal surgery.

 

A tray of specialized instruments is used for nasogastric tube insertion, including a lubricating jelly, an NG tube, a syringe, and gloves, among others.

choices.text: Removing clothes to inspect for wounds
Taking CT scan of the patient

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the primary survey? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Taking CT scan of the patient

 

Taking CT scan of the patient: Incorrect. This is not part of the primary survey. After the primary survey, if the patient is stabilized, a secondary survey is conducted which is a more thorough examination and may involve advanced imaging like CT scans to further delineate injuries.

 

Taking a CT scan of the patient is a part of secondary survey.

 

Primary survey consists of five components, remembered by the mnemonic "ABCDE":

 

  1. Airway maintenance with cervical spine protection: The first step is to ensure the patient has a patent (open) airway, and to protect the cervical spine in case of potential injury.
  2. Breathing and ventilation: This step includes assessing the patient's breathing and ventilation. This can involve checking for symmetric chest rise, listening for breath sounds, and looking for any signs of respiratory distress or chest injury.
  3. Circulation with haemorrhage control: This involves assessing the patient's circulation and looking for signs of active bleeding. Measures such as fluid resuscitation may be initiated during this step if the patient is in shock.
  4. Disability: This involves a quick evaluation of the patient's neurological status, often using the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS).
  5. Exposure/Environmental control: The patient should be fully undressed to allow a complete examination. However, care should be taken to prevent hypothermia, which can worsen outcomes in trauma patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measuring blood pressure: This is a part of assessing Circulation.

 

Option B. Removing clothes to inspect for wounds: This is a part of Exposure/Environmental control. It's crucial to remove clothing so that injuries aren't missed. However, while ensuring exposure, care should also be taken to maintain the patient's body temperature and prevent hypothermia.

 

Option D. Checking airway patency: This is part of Airway maintenance with cervical spine protection. Ensuring a clear airway is a top priority. Airway obstruction takes least time to death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary survey in trauma care includes Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure/Environmental control. Advanced imaging studies like CT scans are part of the secondary survey, conducted after initial stabilization.

questions.text: Which vaccine is not recommended to be given before splenectomy in a 5-year-old child with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Typhoid vaccine

 

The typhoid vaccine is typically not recommended before splenectomy in a child with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism. Typhoid vaccination may lead to a transient decrease in platelet count, which can exacerbate the existing hypersplenism and increase the risk of bleeding. Therefore, it is often deferred until after splenectomy when the risk of post-vaccination thrombocytopenia is reduced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumococcal vaccine: The pneumococcal vaccine is recommended for individuals with asplenia (absence of the spleen) or hyposplenism (reduced spleen function) because they are at an increased risk of severe infections, including those caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae. However, for individuals with hereditary spherocytosis who have an intact spleen, the pneumococcal vaccine may be administered as part of routine immunization.

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenza B vaccine: The Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) vaccine is recommended as part of routine childhood immunization and does not have specific contraindications related to hereditary spherocytosis or splenectomy.

 

Option D. Meningococcal vaccine: The meningococcal vaccine is recommended for individuals with asplenia or hyposplenism, as they are at an increased risk of meningococcal infections. However, for individuals with hereditary spherocytosis who have an intact spleen, the meningococcal vaccine may be administered as part of routine immunization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Typhoid vaccine is often deferred in children with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism before splenectomy due to the risk of transiently reduced platelet count, which can be problematic in the presence of hypersplenism. Other vaccines, such as the pneumococcal, Haemophilus influenzae B, and meningococcal vaccines, may be administered based on routine immunization recommendations and the individual's spleen status.

choices.text: Ileocolic, right colic and branch of middle colic
Ileocolic, right colic, stem of middle colic, left colic
Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient has been diagnosed with proximal transverse colon carcinoma. The physician recommends an extended right colectomy as a treatment option. Which arteries should be resected during an extended right colectomy to prevent the spread of cancer in proximal transverse colon carcinoma? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic.

 

During an extended right colectomy, the ileocolic, right colic, and trunk of the middle colic vessels are typically resected to prevent the spread of cancer in proximal transverse colon carcinoma.

 

The stem of the middle colic and the left colic artery are not resected during an extended right colectomy as they are not directly involved with the blood supply to the proximal transverse colon. It is important to note that the surgical management of colon cancer depends on the stage and location of the tumor and may involve various surgical techniques, including colectomy and lymphadenectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of radical colectomies and vessels ligated:

 

  1. Right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic, right colic and right branch of middle colic artery
  2. Extended right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic, right colic and stem/origin of middle colic artery
  3. Left hemicolectomy: Left colic and sigmoid artery

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, and jaundice. Imaging studies reveal a mass arising from the antrum of the stomach extending into the head of the pancreas with metastasis to the right lobe of the liver. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy

 

  • The clinical scenario involves carcinoma stomach infiltrating into the pancreas with liver metastasis.
  • Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy is the management of choice for such cases.
  • It is a type of palliative surgery that relieves the symptoms of gastric outlet obstruction caused by tumors in the distal stomach or duodenum.
  • The procedure allows food to bypass the obstruction and enter the small intestine, improving the patient's ability to eat and preventing malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option B. Radical gastrectomy: Radical gastrectomy involves the surgical removal of the stomach with the aim of curing the disease. This option is typically considered for localized gastric cancer that has not metastasized extensively.

 

Option C. Whipple's procedure (Pancreaticoduodenectomy): The Whipple's procedure is a complex surgical operation that involves the removal of the head of the pancreas, the duodenum, a portion of the bile duct, and sometimes part of the stomach. It is typically performed for cancers located in the head of the pancreas, not stomach cancer.

 

Option D. Gastrectomy with right hepatectomy: This surgical approach involves the removal of the stomach (gastrectomy) and the right lobe of the liver. It might be considered if the tumor is locally advanced and involves both the stomach and liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For patients with advanced gastric cancer extending into adjacent organs and with liver metastasis, the appropriate management often involves palliative measures, such as gastrojejunostomy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life, followed by chemotherapy.
  • Curative surgical options are generally not feasible in the presence of metastasis.

questions.text: While doing endoscopy a constriction is noted at the level of 25 cm from incisors. Identify the probable cause of the constriction? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arch of aorta

 

During an endoscopy, constrictions of the esophagus can be identified at specific distances from the upper incisors. These constrictions are due to anatomical structures that come in close proximity to or cross the esophagus. At the level of 25 cm from the incisors, the probable cause of constriction is the arch of the aorta.

 

Anatomical Constrictions of the Esophagus:

 

  1. Junction with Cricopharynx (15 cm from incisors):
    • The first constriction occurs where the esophagus joins the cricopharynx, at approximately 15 cm from the upper incisors.
  2. Crossed by Arch of Aorta and Left Bronchus (25 cm from incisors):
    • The second constriction is due to the arch of the aorta and the left principal bronchus crossing the esophagus. This occurs at about 25 cm from the upper incisors.
  3. Diaphragmatic Hiatus (40 cm from incisors):
    • The third constriction occurs where the esophagus passes through the diaphragm, at around 40 cm from the upper incisors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left Upper Bronchus: The left principal (main) bronchus, not the left upper bronchus, can contribute to the constriction at 25 cm from the incisors.

 

Option C. Right Upper Bronchus: The right upper bronchus does not cause a constriction in the esophagus.

 

Option D. Right Lower Bronchus: The right lower bronchus does not cause a constriction in the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The constriction of the esophagus observed at 25 cm from the upper incisors during an endoscopy is most commonly due to the crossing of the esophagus by the arch of the aorta and the left principal bronchus.
